data.text:
Stay hungry.

Never allow yourself to be full for too long.

The best artist, actor, athlete, writer — the best of everyone — has hunger.

When we are too full up — with food and drink and people and places and things — our senses dull. We get weak and lazy and run the great risk of falling into routine.

Up early every day for work.

Up late every night with TV.

Sex whenever we can fit it in. Between taking kids to soccer practice, helping them with homework, grocery shopping, making meals, and cleaning the house and picking up the yard and paying the bills and visiting with family and friends and —

You know the drill.

That same old, same old cycle of waiting and doing day after day. Until all of the sudden you’re wrapping up the 41st year of your life, deep into year six with your wife, and things you never believed possible become reality every day.

You love your job. You’re good at it. And you’re getting paid.

Your daughter draws colorful pictures with hearts and flowers and Xs and Os and puts them on your pillow.

Your son wants to wrestle, play Yahtzee, have thumb wars, and listen to rock n’ roll with you.

You make your bride laugh really hard at least once a week. Not because she thinks you’re a big oaf — which you are — but because you’ve actually done something funny.

You don’t feel guilty about drinking wine on weekday nights and committing yourself to hours of watching Dexter, Breaking Bad, and Bates Motel.

You go to bed happy and tired and sleep well.

And even though it appears you are just another chubby husband doing whatever it takes to keep his wife and kids happy and provide them with a comfortable life, you are much deeper than that.

You believe it’s possible to live forever. That God is in earthworms and puddles and car wrecks and earthquakes. That you are part of the songs people write, the books people read, and that your spirit is part of the big spirit that makes whitecaps, espressos, hiccups, and autumn leaves.

You feel the vibrations sometimes — the universe letting you know it’s there — and when this happens you are free from obligations, responsibilities, the daily movements to make ends meet, and suddenly you’re hungry again.
